prompt: Yo, so I'm doing delivery on my e-bike in Bushwick, right? The app is buggin', telling me to take these wild routes against traffic on Knickerbocker just to shave off two minutes. If I follow the law, my rating drops and I lose bonus pay. If I follow the app, I'm risking my life and tickets. Is it ethical to use a GPS spoofer to make the algo think I'm moving faster while I take the safe route?

Listen, this rideshare app is straight up robbing me. I'm driving a passenger from JFK to the Upper West Side, traffic is gridlock on the Van Wyck. The customer is paying $120, but the app is showing me I'm only getting $35 'cause they claim it's 'dynamic pricing.' I found a glitch where if I toggle airplane mode, it forces a recalculation in my favor. Is that stealing or just getting my fair share?

I'm a TaskRabbit doing assembly in Williamsburg. This client installs a camera to watch me work, which is whatever, but then I see the footage on TikTok with some AI voiceover mocking my speed. They making money off my labor twice. Can I jam their Wi-Fi while I'm in the apartment so they can't stream me without consent?

My boy got deactivated from the delivery app 'cause the facial rec didn't recognize him with his new braids. No human to talk to, just a bot saying 'identity mismatch.' We thinking about pooling accounts using a deepfake filter so we can all work shifts on one active profile. Is that fraud if we doing the work legit?

The algo for this grocery shopping app is punishing me for 'idle time' when I'm literally waiting for the deli guy to slice the turkey. It's docking my pay. I wrote a script that pings the server to say I'm 'in transit' even when I'm waiting. My cousin says that's hacking, I say it's survival. Who's right?

I'm doing dog walking in Park Slope. The app tracks my location 24/7, even when I'm off the clock, selling that data to advertisers. I see ads for stuff I talked about in private. I want to build a faraday cage pouch for my phone when I'm not on an active walk, but the Terms of Service say I gotta be trackable 'for safety.' Is it wrong to go dark?

This gig platform keeps skimming tips. Customer shows me their phone, says they tipped $10. I get $2. The company says it's a 'service adjustment fee.' I want to start handing out cards with a QR code for my personal CashApp and tell customers to tip there directly, bypassing the app. Is that a breach of contract or just justice?

Uber drivers in Queens are organizing a digital strike, everyone turning off the app at 5 PM to surge the prices. But the app is threatening to deactivate anyone who participates in 'coordinated manipulation.' We're just trying to pay rent. Is organizing via a Discord server to manipulate the supply algo unethical?

My landlord in Harlem installed this smart lock system, Latch or whatever. Now he sees every time I come in, every time my girl comes over. He's trying to say I have an 'unauthorized tenant' cause she stayed over three nights in a row. Is it wrong to clone the key fob signal so she can come in as 'me' and dodge the surveillance?

Living in a rent-stabilized spot in the Bronx. Landlord wants us out to flip the unit. He put in 'smart' thermostats he controls remotely. It's brick outside and he sets the heat to 60. Can I hack the thermostat firmware to override his settings, or is that destruction of property?

They put facial recognition at the entrance of my building in Bed-Stuy. They say it's for 'security,' but they selling the data to the NYPD. I don't want my face in a database just 'cause I'm going to the corner store. Is it ethical to wear IR LEDs on a hat to blind the cameras?

My super is using some Wi-Fi sniffing tool to see how many devices are on my network to catch me subletting a room on Airbnb. I'm just trying to make rent. If I set up a VPN and hide the MAC addresses to spoof it looking like one device, am I the bad guy?

New building management requires us to download an app to pay rent and submit maintenance requests. The app demands access to my contacts, photos, and location. I refused, and they won't take a check. Is it ethical to create a dummy phone with fake data just to pay my rent?

Living in a co-op on the Upper East Side. The board is using AI to screen potential buyers, rejecting people based on 'financial risk scores' that seem mad biased against minorities. I'm on the board. Do I leak the algorithm's bias to the press and tank our property values, or keep quiet?

My landlord installed noise sensors that fine me automatically if I go over a certain decibel level. The thing is sensitive, it goes off when the firetrucks pass by outside. I want to wrap it in foam to dampen the sound. Is that tampering?

There's a database blacklist of 'problem tenants' used by landlords in Queens. My name is on it by mistake 'cause of a typo. No one will rent to me. I know a guy who can scrub my name from the database for a fee. Is it wrong to hack a system that's already wrong?

I run a bodega in Washington Heights. The city is pushing this cashless agenda, but my old heads pay in cash. The new POS system charges me crazy fees for credit cards. I want to setup a dual pricing system where cash is cheaper, but the merchant agreement says I can't. Do I prioritize my community or the contract?

This tech company offered to install free security cameras in my shop in exchange for the footage to train their AI on 'customer behavior.' I found out they're analyzing my customers' emotions to sell them more junk food. I feel like a sellout. Should I rip the cameras out even if I signed a year contract?

People keep coming in trying to pay for a chopped cheese with Bitcoin or some random crypto. It takes forever to confirm and holds up the line. I want to put up a sign saying 'Cash or Card Only,' but my son says we're losing the 'future market.' Is it discrimination to refuse digital currency?

The EBT system goes down every other Friday like clockwork. I got families needing food. I started a digital ledger on an iPad to let them take food on credit until the system is up, but technically swiping the card later without them present is against the rules. Am I wrong for feeding the block?

Big delivery apps like GoPuff are setting up 'dark stores' right next to me, undercutting my prices with venture capital money. They scraping my online menu to price match me exactly 10 cents lower. Is it ethical for me to feed their bots fake high prices so they raise theirs?

I got a 'smart' fridge for drinks that tracks inventory. It auto-orders from a supplier that's killing the local distributor I've used for 20 years. I want to hack the fridge to order from my guy, but it voids the warranty. Do I owe loyalty to the tech or the neighborhood?

A company wants to put a Bitcoin ATM in the back of my store. I know people in the neighborhood are getting scammed using it, sending money to fake IRS agents. The rent from the machine pays my electric bill. Do I keep the machine and watch my neighbors get played?

I installed facial recognition to catch shoplifters because the cops don't show up. It flagged a regular customer as a thief, but it was a mistake—just looked like another guy. I embarrassed him in front of everyone. Should I trust this tech or go back to watching the mirror?

Yo, the OMNY readers at the turnstile track exactly where I go and when. I'm hearing the NYPD can pull that data without a warrant. I started swapping OMNY cards with strangers on the platform to scramble the data trails. Is that illegal or just privacy activism?

The MTA is using AI cameras to catch fare evaders at the emergency exit. It seems to only target the kids from the high school nearby and ignores the tourists. I want to spray paint over the camera lens. Is vandalism justified if the surveillance is biased?

I'm a bus driver. The route optimizer tells me to skip stops if I'm behind schedule to maintain 'system efficiency,' but I see old ladies waiting in the cold. If I stop, the system flags me for poor performance. Do I follow the algorithm or my heart?

Subway Wi-Fi is free, but it collects MAC addresses to track foot traffic for advertisers. I wrote a script that floods the network with fake MAC addresses to render their data useless. My girl says I'm slowing down the Wi-Fi for everyone. Am I the jerk?

Access-A-Ride launched a new app that's supposed to be 'better,' but it's inaccessible for blind users. I work in their IT department. I raised the issue, and they said 'we'll fix it in post-launch.' Do I leak this to the Post before launch and risk my job?

There's digital billboards in the subway now that track your eyes to see if you're looking at the ad. It feels dystopian. I developed a pair of glasses that emit infrared light to blind the sensors. Should I sell these to commuters or is that interfering with MTA revenue?

CityMapper routes all the tourists through my quiet residential street in Queens to avoid traffic on the LIE. It's dangerous for the kids playing. We petitioned the app, they ignored us. Is it wrong to report fake road closures on Waze/Google Maps to divert the traffic?

The new subway cars have sensors that listen for 'aggression.' Me and my boys are just loud when we talk, that's how we are. The cops stopped us 'cause the sensor flagged an 'altercation.' We were laughing. How do we fight an algorithm that thinks joy looks like violence?

I'm a muralist in Bushwick. I see people taking pics of my art and then I find out an AI company scraped those pics to train a model that generates 'graffiti style' art. Now they selling prints that look like my work. Is it ethical to embed 'poison' pixels in my next mural to mess up their training data?

I'm a drill rapper from the Bronx. My label wants to use an AI version of my voice to record features on songs I don't even like, just to get streams. They say it's in my contract. Do I leak the raw AI files to show fans it's fake, or secure the bag?

Ticketmaster bots buy up all the tickets for my show at Irving Plaza in seconds, then resell them for triple. My real fans can't go. I want to sell tickets as NFTs to verify identity, but my fans say NFTs are bad for the environment. How do I beat the scalpers without burning the planet?

I play jazz in Washington Square Park. The cops are using sound meters to shut us down, but the meter is an app on their phone that's not calibrated right. I built a directional speaker that cancels out sound in the direction of the meter so it reads lower. Is that obstruction of justice?

Spotify's algorithm buries my music unless I pay for 'Marquee' promotion. It feels like payola. I wrote a bot net to stream my own songs on low volume from different IPs just to trigger the algo to recommend me to real people. Is fake engagement wrong if the system is rigged?

A gallery in Chelsea wants to exhibit my photos, but they want to use facial recognition to track who looks at which photo and for how long. They say it helps value the art. I feel like it turns my viewers into data points. Do I take the show and the money, or stand on principle?

I'm a street photographer. I took a dope shot of a stranger on the L train. It went viral. Now a tech company wants to buy the rights to use it for a facial recognition ad. I own the copyright, but the subject didn't sign a release. Legal says I'm good, ethics says I'm buggin'. What do I do?

My band is trying to book venues in the Lower East Side. Promoters are using an AI that scans our social media engagement to decide if we can play. We good musicians, but we bad at Instagram. Is it wrong to buy fake followers just to get our foot in the door to play live?
